ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Height of the area on texture

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION:
The drawing function. Arguments are:
* [number](/gmod/number) x - X coordinate for the box
* [number](/gmod/number) y - Y coordinate for the box
* [number](/gmod/number) w - Width of the box
* [number](/gmod/number) h - Height of the box
* [table](/gmod/table) clr - Optional color, default is white. Uses the [Color](/gmod/Color)

TextureColor.DESCRIPTION: When used in a material skin, it returns a color value from a point in the skin image.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: x
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: X position of the pixel to get the color from.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: y
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Y position of the pixel to get the color from.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The color of the point on the skin as a [Color](/gmod/Color).

GWEN.DESCRIPTION: GWEN is a system that allows you to load a spritesheet and generate a skin out of it.

Add.DESCRIPTION: Applies a [halo](/gmod/halo) glow effect to one or multiple entities.
NOTES: The ignoreZ parameter will cause the halos to draw over the player's viewmodel. You can work around this using render.DepthRange in the GM:PreDrawViewModel, GM:PostDrawViewModel, GM:PreDrawPlayerHands and GM:PostDrawPlayerHands hooks.
WARNINGS: Using this function outside of the GM:PreDrawHalos hook can cause instability or crashes.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: entities
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: A table of entities to add the halo effect to.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: color
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The desired color of the halo. See [Color](/gmod/Color).

ARGUMENTS.NAME: blurX
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The strength of the halo's blur on the x axis.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: blurY
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The strength of the halo's blur on the y axis.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: passes
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The number of times the halo should be drawn per frame. **Increasing this may hinder player FPS**.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: additive
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Sets the render mode of the halo to additive.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: ignoreZ
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Renders the halo through anything when set to `true`.

Render.DESCRIPTION: Renders a halo according to the specified table, only used internally, called from a [GM:PostDrawEffects](/gmod/GM:PostDrawEffects) hook added by the halo library.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: entry
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Table with info about the halo to draw.

RenderedEntity.DESCRIPTION:
Returns the entity the halo library is currently rendering the halo for.

The main purpose of this function is to be used in [ENTITY:Draw](/gmod/ENTITY:Draw) in order not to draw certain parts of the entity when the halo is being rendered, so there's no halo around unwanted entity parts, such as lasers, 3D2D displays, etc.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: If set, the currently rendered entity by the halo library.

halo.DESCRIPTION: The halo library is used to draw glowing outlines around entities, an example of this can be seen by picking up props with the physgun in Garry's Mod 13.

SendCommand.DESCRIPTION: Sends command to Hammer, if Hammer is running with the current map loaded.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: cmd
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION:
Command to send including arguments

All commands are in the format "command var1 var2 etc"

All commands that pick an entity with x y z , must use the exact position including decimals. i.e. -354.4523 123.4 

# List of commands

| Command       | Description   |

| ------------- | ------------- |

| "session_begin mapName mapVersion" | Starts a hammer edit, locking the editor. mapName is the current map without path or suffix, mapVersion is the current version in the .vmf file |

| "session_end" | Ends a hammer edit, unlocking the editor. |

| "map_check_version mapName mapVersion" | This only works after session_begin, so you'd know the right version already and this only returns ok, this function is apparently useless. |

| "entity_create entityClass x y z" | Creates an entity of entityClass at position x y z |

| "entity_delete entityClass x y z" | Deletes an entity of entityClass at position x y z |

| "entity_set_keyvalue entityClass x y z "key" "value"" | Set's the KeyValue pair of an entity of entityClass at x y z. The Key name and Value String must be in quotes. |

| "entity_rotate_incremental entityClass x y z incX incY incZ" | Rotates an entity of entityClass at x y z by incX incY incZ |

| "node_create nodeClass nodeID x y z" | Creates an AI node of nodeClass with nodeID at x y z you should keep nodeID unique or you will have issues |

| "node_delete nodeID" | Deletes node(s) with nodeID, this will delete multiple nodes if they have the same nodeID |

| "nodelink_create startNodeID endNodeID" | Creates a link between AI nodes startNodeID and endNodeID |

| "nodelink_delete startNodeID endNodeID" | Removes a link between AI nodes startNodeID and endNodeID |

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION:
Returns "ok" if command succeeded otherwise returns "badcommand"

**All changes only happen in hammer, there is *NO* in game representation/feedback**

Add.DESCRIPTION: Add a hook to be called upon the given event occurring.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: eventName
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The event to hook on to. This can be any [GM](/gmod/GM_Hooks) hook, gameevent after using [gameevent.Listen](/gmod/gameevent.Listen), or custom hook run with [hook.Call](/gmod/hook.Call) or [hook.Run](/gmod/hook.Run).

ARGUMENTS.NAME: identifier
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION:
The unique identifier, usually a string. This can be used elsewhere in the code to replace or remove the hook. The identifier **should** be unique so that you do not accidentally override some other mods hook, unless that's what you are trying to do.

The identifier can be either a [string](/gmod/string), or a [table](/gmod/table)/object with an IsValid function defined such as an [Entity](/gmod/Entity) or [Panel](/gmod/Panel). [number](/gmod/number)s and [boolean](/gmod/boolean)s, for example, are not allowed.

If the identifier is a table/object, it will be inserted in front of the other arguments in the callback and the hook will be called as long as it's valid. However, as soon as IsValid( identifier ) returns false, the hook will be removed.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: func
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The function to be called, arguments given to it depend on the .
WARNINGS:
Returning any value besides nil from the hook's function will stop other hooks of the same event down the loop from being executed. Only return a value when absolutely necessary and when you know what you are doing.

It WILL break other addons.

Call.DESCRIPTION:
Calls all hooks associated with the given event until one returns something other than nil, and then returns that data.

In almost all cases, you should use [hook.Run](/gmod/hook.Run) instead - it calls hook.Call internally but supplies the gamemode table by itself, making your code neater.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: eventName
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The event to call hooks for

ARGUMENTS.NAME: gamemodeTable
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: If the gamemode is specified, the gamemode hook within will be called, otherwise not

ARGUMENTS.NAME: args
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The arguments to be passed to the hooks

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: Return data from called hooks. Limited to 6 return values

GetTable.DESCRIPTION: Returns a list of all the hooks registered with [hook.Add](/gmod/hook.Add).

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: A table of tables. See below for output example.

Remove.DESCRIPTION: Removes the hook with the supplied identifier from the given event.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: eventName
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The event name.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: identifier
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The unique identifier of the hook to remove, usually a string.

Run.DESCRIPTION:
Calls hooks associated with the given event.

Calls all hooks until one returns something other than nil and then returns that data.

If no hook returns any data, it will try to call the GAMEMODE:<eventName> alternative, if one exists.

This function internally calls [hook.Call](/gmod/hook.Call).

See also: [gamemode.Call](/gmod/gamemode.Call) - same as this, but does not call hooks if the gamemode hasn't defined the function.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: eventName
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The event to call hooks for

ARGUMENTS.NAME: args
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The arguments to be passed to the hooks

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: Returned data from called hooks

hook.DESCRIPTION: The hook library allows you to add hooks called by the game engine, allowing multiple scripts to modify game function.

Fetch.DESCRIPTION:
Launches an asynchronous **GET** request to a HTTP server.

HTTP requests returning a status code >= `400` are still considered a success and will call the [onSuccess](/gmod/Structures/HTTPRequest) callback.

The [onFailure](/gmod/Structures/HTTPRequest) callback is usually only called on DNS or TCP errors (e.g. the website is unavailable or the domain does not exist).
NOTES: HTTP-requests to destinations on private networks (such as `192.168.0.1`) won't work. To enable HTTP-requests to destinations on private networks use Command Line Parameters `-allowlocalhttp`.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: url
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The URL of the website to fetch.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: onSuccess
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION:
Function to be called on success. Arguments are

* [string](/gmod/string) body

* [string](/gmod/string) size - equal to [string.len](/gmod/string.len)(body).

* [table](/gmod/table) headers

* [number](/gmod/number) code - The HTTP success code.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: onFailure
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION:
Function to be called on failure. Arguments are

* [string](/gmod/string) error - The error message.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: headers
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: KeyValue table for headers.

Post.DESCRIPTION:
Sends an asynchronous **POST** request to a HTTP server.

HTTP requests returning a status code >= `400` are still considered a success and will call the [onSuccess](/gmod/Structures/HTTPRequest) callback.

The [onFailure](/gmod/Structures/HTTPRequest) callback is usually only called on DNS or TCP errors (e.g. the website is unavailable or the domain does not exist).
NOTES: HTTP-requests to destinations on private networks (such as `192.168.0.1`) won't work. To enable HTTP-requests to destinations on private networks use Command Line Parameters `-allowlocalhttp`.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: url
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The url to of the website to post.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: parameters
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The post parameters (x-www-form-urlencoded) to be send to the server. **Keys and values must be strings**.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: onSuccess
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION:
Function to be called on success. Arguments are

* [string](/gmod/string) body

* [string](/gmod/string) size - equal to [string.len](/gmod/string.len)(body).

* [table](/gmod/table) headers

* [number](/gmod/number) code - The HTTP success code.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: onFailure
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION:
Function to be called on failure. Arguments are

* [string](/gmod/string) error - The error message.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: headers
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: KeyValue table for headers.

http.DESCRIPTION: The http library allows either the server or client to communicate with external websites via HTTP, both GET ([http.Fetch](/gmod/http.Fetch)) and POST ([http.Post](/gmod/http.Post)) are supported. A more powerful & advanced method can be used via the global [HTTP](/gmod/Global.HTTP) function.

WasKeyPressed.DESCRIPTION:
Returns whether a key was initially pressed in the same frame this function was called.

This function only works in Move hooks, and will detect key presses even in main menu or when a typing in a text field.

ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The key, see [KEY](/gmod/Enums/KEY).

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: True if the key was initially pressed the same frame that this function was called, false otherwise.

WasKeyReleased.DESCRIPTION:
Returns whether a key was released in the same frame this function was called.

This function only works in Move hooks, and will detect key releases even in main menu or when a typing in a text field.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: True if the key was released the same frame that this function was called, false otherwise.

WasKeyTyped.DESCRIPTION:
Returns whether the key is being held down or not.

WasMouseDoublePressed.DESCRIPTION:
Returns whether a mouse key was double pressed in the same frame this function was called.

If this function returns true, [input.WasMousePressed](/gmod/input.WasMousePressed) will return false.

This function only works in Move hooks, and will detect mouse events even in main menu or when a typing in a text field.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: button
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The mouse button to test, see [MOUSE](/gmod/Enums/MOUSE)

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: Whether the mouse key was double pressed or not.

WasMousePressed.DESCRIPTION:
Returns whether a mouse key was initially pressed in the same frame this function was called.

If [input.WasMouseDoublePressed](/gmod/input.WasMouseDoublePressed) returns true, this function will return false.

This function only works in Move hooks, and will detect mouse events even in main menu or when a typing in a text field.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: key
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The key, see [MOUSE](/gmod/Enums/MOUSE)

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: True if the mouse key was initially pressed the same frame that this function was called, false otherwise.

WasMouseReleased.DESCRIPTION:
Returns whether a mouse key was released in the same frame this function was called.

This function only works in Move hooks, and will detect mouse events even in main menu or when a typing in a text field.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: key
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The key to test, see [MOUSE](/gmod/Enums/MOUSE)

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: True if the mouse key was released the same frame that this function was called, false otherwise.

input.DESCRIPTION: The input library allows you to gather information about the clients input devices (mouse & keyboard), such as the cursor position and whether a key is pressed or not.

start.DESCRIPTION:
JIT compiler optimization control. The opt sub-module provides the backend for the -O command line LuaJIT option.

You can also use it programmatically, e.g.:

```

jit.opt.start(2) -- same as -O2

jit.opt.start("-dce")

jit.opt.start("hotloop=10", "hotexit=2")

```

	A list of LuaJIT -O command line options can be found here(a table of various optimization levels are displayed towards the bottom of the page along with exactly which optimization options are enabled for each level): http://luajit.org/running.html

funcbc.DESCRIPTION: Returns bytecode of a function at a position.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: func
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Function to retrieve bytecode from.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: pos
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Position of the bytecode to retrieve.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: bytecode instruction
bytecode opcode

funcinfo.DESCRIPTION:
Retrieves LuaJIT information about a given function, similarly to [debug.getinfo](/gmod/debug.getinfo). Possible table fields:
* linedefined: as for [debug.getinfo](/gmod/debug.getinfo)
* lastlinedefined: as for [debug.getinfo](/gmod/debug.getinfo)
* params: the number of parameters the function takes
* stackslots: the number of stack slots the function's local variable use
* upvalues: the number of upvalues the function uses
* bytecodes: the number of bytecodes it the compiled function
* gcconsts: the number of garbage collectable constants
* nconsts: the number of lua_Number (double) constants
* children: Boolean representing whether the function creates closures
* currentline: as for [debug.getinfo](/gmod/debug.getinfo)
* isvararg: if the function is a vararg function
* source: as for [debug.getinfo](/gmod/debug.getinfo)
* loc: a string describing the source and currentline, like "<source>:<line>"
* ffid: the fast function id of the function (if it is one). In this case only upvalues above and addr below are valid
* addr: the address of the function (if it is not a Lua function). If it's a C function rather than a fast function, only upvalues above is valid*

ARGUMENTS.NAME: func
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Function or Proto to retrieve info about.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: Information about the supplied function/proto.

funck.DESCRIPTION: Gets a constant at a certain index in a function.
NOTES: This function only works for Lua defined functions.
Numbers constants goes from 0 (included) to n-1, n being the value of nconsts in jit.util.funcinfo in other words, the consts goes from (nconsts-1) to -n
WARNINGS: This function isn't officially documented on LuJIT wiki, use it at your own risk.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: func
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Function to get constant from

ARGUMENTS.NAME: index
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Constant index (counting down from the top of the function at -1)

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The constant found.
NOTES: This will return a proto for functions that are created inside the target function - see Example 2.

funcuvname.DESCRIPTION: Does the exact same thing as debug.getupvalue except it only returns the name, not the name and the object. The upvalue indexes also start at 0 rather than 1, so doing jit.util.funcuvname(func, 0) will get you the same name as debug.getupvalue(func, 1)
WARNINGS: This function isn't officially documented on LuJIT wiki, use it at your own risk.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: func
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Function to get the upvalue indexed from

ARGUMENTS.NAME: index
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The upvalue index, starting from 0

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The function returns nil if there is no upvalue with the given index, otherwise the name of the upvalue is returned

ircalladdr.DESCRIPTION: Gets the address of a function from a list of 20 functions, for the list see [Ircalladdr Functions](/gmod/Ircalladdr Functions)
WARNINGS: This function isn't officially documented on LuJIT wiki, use it at your own risk.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: index
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The index of the function address to get from the ircalladdr func array (starting from 0)

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The address of the function

ARGUMENTS.NAME: exitno
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: exit number to retrieve exit stub address from (gotten via [jit.attach](/gmod/jit.attach) with the texit event)

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: exitstub trace address

traceinfo.DESCRIPTION:
Return table fields:
* link (number): the linked trace (0 for link types: none, return, interpreter)
* nk (number): the lowest IR constant (???)
* nins (number): the next IR instruction (???)
* linktype (string): the link type (none, root, loop, tail-recursion, up-recursion, down-recursion, interpreter, return)
* nexit (number): number of snapshots (for use with [jit.util.tracesnap](/gmod/jit.util.tracesnap))

ARGUMENTS.NAME: trace
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: trace index to retrieve info for (gotten via [jit.attach](/gmod/jit.attach))

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: trace info
m
ot
op1
op2
prev
k
t
slot; optional
mcode
address
loop

tracesnap.DESCRIPTION:
Return table fields:
* 0 (ref) (number): first IR ref for the snapshot
* 1 (nslots) (number): the number of valid slots 
* all indexes except first 2 and last (there might not be any of these): the snapshot map
* last index in table (number): -16777216 (255 << 24)

ARGUMENTS.NAME: tr
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: trace index to retrieve snapshot for (gotten via [jit.attach](/gmod/jit.attach))

ARGUMENTS.NAME: sn
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: snapshot index for trace (starting from 0 to nexit - 1, nexit gotten via [jit.util.traceinfo](/gmod/jit.util.traceinfo))

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: snapshot

WARNINGS: This function isn't officially documented on LuJIT wiki, use it at your own risk.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: callback
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION:
The callback function.

The arguments passed to the callback depend on the event being reported:

* "bc":
[function](/gmod/function) func - The function that's just been recorded

* "trace":
[string](/gmod/string) what - description of the trace event: "flush", "start", "stop", "abort". Available for all events.

[number](/gmod/number) tr - The trace number. Not available for flush.

[function](/gmod/function) func - The function being traced. Available for start and abort.

[number](/gmod/number) pc - The program counter - the bytecode number of the function being recorded (if this a Lua function). Available for start and abort.

[number](/gmod/number) otr - start: the parent trace number if this is a side trace, abort: abort code

[string](/gmod/string) oex - start: the exit number for the parent trace, abort: abort reason (string)

* "record":
[number](/gmod/number) tr - The trace number. Not available for flush.

[function](/gmod/function) func - The function being traced. Available for start and abort.

[number](/gmod/number) pc - The program counter - the bytecode number of the function being recorded (if this a Lua function). Available for start and abort.

[number](/gmod/number) depth  - The depth of the inlining of the current bytecode.

* "texit":
[number](/gmod/number) tr - The trace number. Not available for flush.

[number](/gmod/number) ex - The exit number

[number](/gmod/number) ngpr - The number of general-purpose and floating point registers that are active at the exit.

[number](/gmod/number) nfpr - The number of general-purpose and floating point registers that are active at the exit.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: event
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The event to hook into.

flush.DESCRIPTION: Flushes the whole cache of compiled code.

status.DESCRIPTION: Returns the status of the JIT compiler and the current optimizations enabled.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: Is JIT enabled
Strings for CPU-specific features and enabled optimizations

version_num.DESCRIPTION:
# Not a function

This is NOT a function, it's a variable containing the version number of the LuaJIT core. Version `xx.yy.zz` is represented by the decimal number `xxyyzz`. In GMod this is `20004`. On x86-64 branch it's `20100`.

asin.DESCRIPTION: Returns the [arcsine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inverse_trigonometric_functions) of the given number.

[nan](/gmod/nan) if the argument is out of range.

atan2.DESCRIPTION: functions like [math.atan](/gmod/math.atan)(y / x), except it also takes into account the quadrant of the angle and so doesn't have a limited range of output.
NOTES: The Y argument comes first!

ARGUMENTS.NAME: y
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Y coordinate.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: x
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: X coordinate.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The angle of the line from (0, 0) to (x, y) in radians, in the range -pi to pi.

calcBSplineN.DESCRIPTION: Basic code for Bezier-Spline algorithm, helper function for [math.BSplinePoint](/gmod/math.BSplinePoint).

exp.DESCRIPTION: Returns the x power of the Euler constant.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: exponent
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The exponent for the function.

floor.DESCRIPTION: Floors or rounds a number down.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: floored numbers

fmod.DESCRIPTION:
Returns the modulus of the specified values.

While this is similar to the % operator, **it will return a negative value if the first argument is negative**, whereas the % operator will return a `positive` value **even if the first operand is negative**.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: base
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The base value.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: modulator
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The modulator.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The calculated modulus.

frexp.DESCRIPTION:
**Lua reference description**: Returns `m` and `e` such that `x = m2e`, `e` is an integer and the absolute value of `m` is in the range ((0.5, 1) (or zero when x is zero).

Used to split the number value into a normalized fraction and an exponent. Two values are returned: the first is a multiplier in the range `1/2` (**inclusive**) to `1` (**exclusive**) and the second is an integer exponent.

The result is such that `x = m*2^e`.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: x
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The value to get the normalized fraction and the exponent from.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: m, multiplier - between `0.5` and `1`.
e, exponent - **always** an integer.

IntToBin.DESCRIPTION: Converts an integer to a binary (base-2) string.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: int
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Number to be converted.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: Binary number string. The length of this will always be a multiple of 3.

ldexp.DESCRIPTION: Takes a normalised number and returns the floating point representation.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: normalizedFraction
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The value to get the normalized fraction and the exponent from.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: exponent
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The value to get the normalized fraction and the exponent from.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: result

log.DESCRIPTION:
With one argument, return the natural logarithm of x (to base e).

With two arguments, return the logarithm of x to the given base, calculated as log(x)/log(base).

ARGUMENTS.NAME: x
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The value to get the base from exponent from.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: base
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The logarithmic base.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: Logarithm of x to the given base

log10.DESCRIPTION: Returns the base-10 logarithm of x. This is usually more accurate than math.log(x, 10).

ARGUMENTS.NAME: x
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The value to get the base from exponent from.

max.DESCRIPTION: Returns the largest value of all arguments.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: numbers
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Numbers to get the largest from

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The largest number

min.DESCRIPTION: Returns the smallest value of all arguments.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: numbers
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Numbers to get the smallest from.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The smallest number

mod.DESCRIPTION: Returns the modulus of the specified values. Same as [math.fmod](/gmod/math.fmod).
DEPRECATED: This is removed in Lua versions later than what GMod is currently using. You should use the % operator or math.fmod instead.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: base
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The base value

ARGUMENTS.NAME: modulator
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Modulator

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The calculated modulus

modf.DESCRIPTION: Returns the integral and fractional component of the modulo operation.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: base
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The base value.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The integral component.
The fractional component.

NormalizeAngle.DESCRIPTION: Normalizes angle, so it returns value between -180 and 180.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: angle
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The angle to normalize, in degrees.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The normalized angle, in the range of -180 to 180 degrees.

pow.DESCRIPTION:
Returns x raised to the power y.

In particular, math.pow(1.0, x) and math.pow(x, 0.0) always return 1.0, even when x is a zero or a [nan](/gmod/nan). If both x and y are finite, x is negative, and y is not an integer then math.pow(x, y) is undefined.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: x
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Base.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: y
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Exponent.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: y power of x

rad.DESCRIPTION: Converts an angle in degrees to it's equivalent in radians.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: degrees
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The angle measured in degrees.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: radians

Rand.DESCRIPTION:
Returns a random float between min and max.

See also [math.random](/gmod/math.random)

ARGUMENTS.NAME: min
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The minimum value.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: max
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The maximum value.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: Random float between min and max.

random.DESCRIPTION:
When called without arguments, returns a uniform pseudo-random real number in the range 0 to 1 which includes 0 but excludes 1.

When called with an integer number m, returns a uniform pseudo-random integer in the range 1 to m inclusive.

When called with two integer numbers m and n, returns a uniform pseudo-random integer in the range m to n inclusive.

See also [math.Rand](/gmod/math.Rand)

ARGUMENTS.NAME: m
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION:
If m is the only parameter: upper limit.

If n is also provided: lower limit.

If provided, this must be an integer.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: n
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION:
Upper limit.

If provided, this must be an integer.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: Random value

randomseed.DESCRIPTION:
Seeds the random number generator. The same seed will guarantee the same sequence of numbers each time with [math.random](/gmod/math.random).

For shared random values across predicted realms, use [util.SharedRandom](/gmod/util.SharedRandom).
WARNINGS: Incorrect usage of this function will affect `all` random numbers in the game.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: seed
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The new seed

pi.DESCRIPTION:
[Trigonometry](/gmod/Trigonometry)

# Floating point precision considerations

It should be noted that due to the nature of floating point numbers, results of calculations with `math.pi` may not be what you expect.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: dir
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The normal of this terrain position.

BeginGeneration.DESCRIPTION: Starts the generation of a new navmesh.
NOTES: This process is highly resource intensive and it's not wise to use during normal gameplay

ClearWalkableSeeds.DESCRIPTION: Clears all the walkable positions, used before calling [navmesh.BeginGeneration](/gmod/navmesh.BeginGeneration).

ARGUMENTS.NAME: corner
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The first corner of the new [CNavArea](/gmod/CNavArea)

ARGUMENTS.NAME: opposite_corner
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The opposite (diagonally) corner of the new [CNavArea](/gmod/CNavArea)

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The new [CNavArea](/gmod/CNavArea) or [nil](/gmod/nil) if we failed for some reason.

Find.DESCRIPTION: Returns a bunch of areas within distance, used to find hiding spots by [NextBot](/gmod/NextBot)s for example.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: pos
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The position to search around

ARGUMENTS.NAME: radius
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Radius to search within

ARGUMENTS.NAME: stepdown
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Maximum stepdown( fall distance ) allowed

ARGUMENTS.NAME: stepup
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Maximum stepup( jump height ) allowed

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: A table of [CNavArea](/gmod/CNavArea)s

GetAllNavAreas.DESCRIPTION: Returns an integer indexed table of all [CNavArea](/gmod/CNavArea)s on the current map. If the map doesn't have a navmesh generated then this will return an empty table.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: A table of all the [CNavArea](/gmod/CNavArea)s on the current map.

GetEditCursorPosition.DESCRIPTION: Returns the position of the edit cursor when nav_edit is set to 1.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The position of the edit cursor.

GetGroundHeight.DESCRIPTION: Finds the closest standable ground at, above, or below the provided position.
NOTES: The ground must have at least 32 units of empty space above it to be considered by this function, unless 16 layers are tested without finding valid ground.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: pos
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Position to find the closest ground for.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The height of the ground layer.
The normal of the ground layer.

GetMarkedArea.DESCRIPTION: Returns the currently marked [CNavArea](/gmod/CNavArea), for use with editing console commands.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The currently marked [CNavArea](/gmod/CNavArea).

GetMarkedLadder.DESCRIPTION: Returns the currently marked [CNavLadder](/gmod/CNavLadder), for use with editing console commands.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The currently marked [CNavLadder](/gmod/CNavLadder).

GetNavArea.DESCRIPTION:
Returns the Nav Area contained in this position that also satisfies the elevation limit.

This function will properly see blocked [CNavArea](/gmod/CNavArea)s. See [navmesh.GetNearestNavArea](/gmod/navmesh.GetNearestNavArea).

ARGUMENTS.NAME: pos
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The position to search for.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: beneathLimit
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The elevation limit at which the Nav Area will be searched.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The nav area.

GetNavAreaByID.DESCRIPTION: Returns a [CNavArea](/gmod/CNavArea) by the given ID.
NOTES: Avoid calling this function every frame, as internally it does a lookup trough all the CNavAreas, call this once and store the result

ARGUMENTS.NAME: id
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: ID of the [CNavArea](/gmod/CNavArea) to get. Starts with 1.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The [CNavArea](/gmod/CNavArea) with given ID.

GetNavAreaCount.DESCRIPTION: Returns the highest ID of all nav areas on the map. While this can be used to get all nav areas, this number may not actually be the actual number of nav areas on the map.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The highest ID of all nav areas on the map.

GetNavLadderByID.DESCRIPTION: Returns a [CNavLadder](/gmod/CNavLadder) by the given ID.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: id
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: ID of the [CNavLadder](/gmod/CNavLadder) to get. Starts with 1.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The [CNavLadder](/gmod/CNavLadder) with given ID.

GetNearestNavArea.DESCRIPTION:
Returns the closest [CNavArea](/gmod/CNavArea) to given position at the same height, or beneath it.

This function will ignore blocked [CNavArea](/gmod/CNavArea)s. See [navmesh.GetNavArea](/gmod/navmesh.GetNavArea) for a function that does see blocked areas.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: pos
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The position to look from

ARGUMENTS.NAME: anyZ
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: This argument is ignored and has no effect

ARGUMENTS.NAME: maxDist
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: This is the maximum distance from the given position that the function will look for a [CNavArea](/gmod/CNavArea)

ARGUMENTS.NAME: checkLOS
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION:
If this is set to true then the function will internally do a [util.TraceLine](/gmod/util.TraceLine) from the starting position to each potential [CNavArea](/gmod/CNavArea) with a [MASK_NPCSOLID_BRUSHONLY](https://wiki.facepunch.com/gmod/Enums/MASK). If the trace fails then the [CNavArea](/gmod/CNavArea) is ignored.

If this is set to false then the function will find the closest [CNavArea](/gmod/CNavArea) through anything, including the world.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: checkGround
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: If checkGround is true then this function will internally call [navmesh.GetNavArea](/gmod/navmesh.GetNavArea) to check if there is a [CNavArea](/gmod/CNavArea) directly below the position, and return it if so, before checking anywhere else.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: team
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: This will internally call [CNavArea:IsBlocked](/gmod/CNavArea:IsBlocked) to check if the target [CNavArea](/gmod/CNavArea) is not to be navigated by the given team. Currently this appears to do nothing.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The closest [CNavArea](/gmod/CNavArea) found with the given parameters, or a NULL [CNavArea](/gmod/CNavArea) if one was not found.

GetPlayerSpawnName.DESCRIPTION: Returns the classname of the player spawn entity.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The classname of the spawn point entity. By default returns "info_player_start"

IsGenerating.DESCRIPTION: Whether we're currently generating a new navmesh with [navmesh.BeginGeneration](/gmod/navmesh.BeginGeneration).

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: Whether we're generating a nav mesh or not.

IsLoaded.DESCRIPTION: Returns true if a navmesh has been loaded when loading the map.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: Whether a navmesh has been loaded when loading the map.

Load.DESCRIPTION: Loads a new navmesh from the .nav file for current map discarding any changes made to the navmesh previously.

Reset.DESCRIPTION: Deletes every [CNavArea](/gmod/CNavArea) and [CNavLadder](/gmod/CNavLadder) on the map **without saving the changes**.

Save.DESCRIPTION: Saves any changes made to navmesh to the .nav file.

SetMarkedArea.DESCRIPTION: Sets the [CNavArea](/gmod/CNavArea) as marked, so it can be used with editing console commands.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: area
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The [CNavArea](/gmod/CNavArea) to set as the marked area.

SetMarkedLadder.DESCRIPTION: Sets the [CNavLadder](/gmod/CNavLadder) as marked, so it can be used with editing console commands.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: area
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The [CNavLadder](/gmod/CNavLadder) to set as the marked ladder.

SetPlayerSpawnName.DESCRIPTION: Sets the classname of the default spawn point entity, used before generating a new navmesh with [navmesh.BeginGeneration](/gmod/navmesh.BeginGeneration).

ARGUMENTS.NAME: spawnPointClass
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The classname of what the player uses to spawn, automatically adds it to the walkable positions during map generation.

navmesh.DESCRIPTION:
The navigation mesh library. To be used with [CNavArea](/gmod/CNavArea).

The navigation mesh is used by [NextBot](/gmod/NextBot) to calculate path to its target.

Broadcast.DESCRIPTION:
Sends the currently built net message to all connected players.
More information can be found in [Net Library Usage](/gmod/Net Library Usage).

BytesLeft.DESCRIPTION: Returns the amount of data left to read in the current message in bytes. Does nothing when sending data.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION:
The amount of data left to read in the current net message in bytes.
Returns nil if no net message has been started.

The amount of data left to read in the current net message in bits.
Returns nil if no net message has been started.

BytesWritten.DESCRIPTION: Returns the size of the current message in bytes.
NOTES: This will include 3 extra bytes used by the engine internally to send the data over the network.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION:
The amount of bytes written to the current net message.
Returns nil if no net message has been started.

The amount of bits written to the current net message.
Returns nil if no net message has been started.

Incoming.DESCRIPTION: Function called by the engine to tell the lua state a message arrived.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: length
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The message length, in bits.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: client
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The player that sent the message. This will be nil in the client state.

ReadAngle.DESCRIPTION: Reads an angle from the received net message.
WARNINGS: You **must** read information in same order as you write it.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The read angle, or Angle(0,0,0) if no angle could be read

ReadBit.DESCRIPTION: Reads a bit from the received net message.
WARNINGS: You **must** read information in same order as you write it.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: 0 or 1, or 0 if the bit could not be read.

ReadBool.DESCRIPTION: Reads a boolean from the received net message.
WARNINGS: You **must** read information in same order as you write it.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: true or false, or false if the bool could not be read.

ReadColor.DESCRIPTION: Reads a [Color](/gmod/Color) from the current net message.
WARNINGS: You **must** read information in same order as you write it.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The [Color](/gmod/Color) read from the current net message, or Color(0,0,0,0) if the color could not be read.

ReadData.DESCRIPTION: Reads pure binary data from the message.
WARNINGS: You **must** read information in same order as you write it.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: length
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The length of the data to be read, in bytes.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The binary data read, or a string containing one character with a byte of 0 if no data could be read.

ReadDouble.DESCRIPTION: Reads a double-precision number from the received net message.
WARNINGS: You **must** read information in same order as you write it.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The double-precision number, or 0 if no number could be read.

ReadEntity.DESCRIPTION: Reads an entity from the received net message. You should always check if the specified entity exists as it may have been removed and therefor NULL if it is outside of the players PVS or was already removed.
WARNINGS: You **must** read information in same order as you write it.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The entity, or Entity(0) if no entity could be read.

ReadFloat.DESCRIPTION: Reads a floating point number from the received net message.
WARNINGS: You **must** read information in same order as you write it.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The floating point number, or 0 if no number could be read.

ReadHeader.DESCRIPTION: Reads a word, basically unsigned short. This is used internally to read the "header" of the message which is an unsigned short which can be converted to the corresponding message name via [util.NetworkIDToString](/gmod/util.NetworkIDToString).

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The header number

ReadInt.DESCRIPTION: Reads an integer from the received net message.
WARNINGS: You **must** read information in same order as you write it.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: bitCount
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION:
The amount of bits to be read.

This must be set to what you set to [net.WriteInt](/gmod/net.WriteInt). Read more information at [net.WriteInt](/gmod/net.WriteInt).

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The read integer number, or 0 if no integer could be read.

ReadMatrix.DESCRIPTION: Reads a [VMatrix](/gmod/VMatrix) from the received net message.
WARNINGS: You **must** read information in same order as you write it.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The matrix, or an empty matrix if no matrix could be read.

ReadNormal.DESCRIPTION: Reads a normal vector from the net message.
WARNINGS: You **must** read information in same order as you write it.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The normalized vector ( length = 1 ), or Vector(0,0,1) if no normal could be read.

ReadString.DESCRIPTION: Reads a null terminated string from the net stream. The size of the string is 8 bits plus 8 bits for every ASCII character in the string.
WARNINGS: You **must** read information in same order as you write it.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The read string, or a string with 0 length if no string could be read.

ReadTable.DESCRIPTION:
Reads a table from the received net message.

See [net.WriteTable](/gmod/net.WriteTable) for extra info.

You may get `net.ReadType: Couldn't read type X` during the execution of the function, the problem is that you are sending objects that cannot be serialized/sent over the network.
NOTES: Sometimes when sending a table through the net library, the order of the keys may be switched. So be cautious when comparing (See Example 1).
WARNINGS: You **must** read information in same order as you write it.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: Table recieved via the net message, or a blank table if no table could be read.

ReadType.DESCRIPTION: Reads a value from the net message with the specified type, written by [net.WriteType](/gmod/net.WriteType).
WARNINGS: You **must** read information in same order as you write it.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: typeID
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The type of value to be read, using [TYPE](/gmod/Enums/TYPE).

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The value, or the respective blank value based on the type you're reading if the value could not be read.

ReadUInt.DESCRIPTION: Reads an unsigned integer with the specified number of bits from the received net message.
WARNINGS: You **must** read information in same order as you write it.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: numberOfBits
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The size of the integer to be read, in bits.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The unsigned integer read, or 0 if the integer could not be read.

ReadVector.DESCRIPTION: Reads a vector from the received net message.  Vectors sent by this function are compressed, which may result in precision loss. See [net.WriteVector](/gmod/net.WriteVector) for more information.
WARNINGS: You **must** read information in same order as you write it.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The read vector, or Vector(0,0,0) if no vector could be read.

Receive.DESCRIPTION: Adds a net message handler. Only one receiver can be used to receive the net message.
NOTES: The message-name is converted to lower-case so the message-names "`BigBlue`" and "`bigblue`" would be equal.
WARNINGS: Each net message has a length limit of 64KB!
You **must** read information in the same order as you write it.
You **must** put this function **outside** of any other function or hook for it to work properly unless you know what you are doing!

ARGUMENTS.NAME: messageName
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The message name to hook to.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: callback
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION:
The function to be called if the specified message was received. Arguments are:

[number](/gmod/number) len - Length of the message, in bits

[Player](/gmod/Player) ply - The player that sent the message, works only serverside

Send.DESCRIPTION: Sends the current message to the specified player, or to all players listed in the table.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: ply
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The player(s) to send the message to. Can be a table of players or a [CRecipientFilter](/gmod/CRecipientFilter).

SendOmit.DESCRIPTION: Sends the current message to all except the specified, or to all except all players in the table.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: ply
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The player(s) to NOT send the message to. Can be a table of players

SendPAS.DESCRIPTION: Sends the message to all players that are in the same potentially audible set(PAS) as the position, or simply said, it adds all players that can potentially hear sounds from this position.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: position
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: PAS position.

SendPVS.DESCRIPTION: Sends the message to all players the position is in the PVS of or, more simply said, sends the message to players that can potentially see this position.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: position
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Position that must be in players' visibility set.

SendToServer.DESCRIPTION: Sends the current message to the server.

Start.DESCRIPTION: Begins a new net message. If another net message is already started and hasn't been sent yet, it will be discarded.
WARNINGS: Each net message has a length limit of 64KB!
The message name must be pooled with util.AddNetworkString beforehand!
Net messages will not reliably reach the client until the client's GM:InitPostEntity hook is called.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: messageName
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The name of the message to send

ARGUMENTS.NAME: unreliable
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: If set to true, the message is not guaranteed to reach its destination

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: True if the message has been started.

WriteAngle.DESCRIPTION: Writes an angle to the current net message.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: angle
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The angle to be sent.

WriteBit.DESCRIPTION:
Appends a boolean (as 1 or 0) to the current net message.

Please note that the bit is written here from a [boolean](/gmod/boolean) (true/false) but [net.ReadBit](/gmod/net.ReadBit) returns a number.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: boolean
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Bit status (false = 0, true = 1)

WriteBool.DESCRIPTION: Appends a boolean to the current net message. Alias of [net.WriteBit](/gmod/net.WriteBit)

ARGUMENTS.NAME: boolean
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Boolean value to write

WriteColor.DESCRIPTION: Appends a [Color](/gmod/Color) to the current net message.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: Color
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The [Color](/gmod/Color) you want to append to the net message.

WriteData.DESCRIPTION: Writes a chunk of binary data to the message.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: binaryData
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The binary data to be sent.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: length
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The length of the binary data to be sent, in bytes.

WriteDouble.DESCRIPTION: Appends a double-precision number to the current net message.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: double
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The double to be sent

WriteEntity.DESCRIPTION: Appends an entity to the current net message.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: entity
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The entity to be sent.

WriteFloat.DESCRIPTION: Appends a float (number with decimals) to the current net message.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: float
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The float to be sent.

WriteInt.DESCRIPTION:
Appends an integer - a whole number - to the current net message. Can be read back with [net.ReadInt](/gmod/net.ReadInt) on the receiving end.

Use [net.WriteUInt](/gmod/net.WriteUInt) to send an unsigned number (that you know will never be negative). Use [net.WriteFloat](/gmod/net.WriteFloat) for a non-whole number (e.g. 2.25).

ARGUMENTS.NAME: integer
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The integer to be sent.

WriteMatrix.DESCRIPTION: Writes a [VMatrix](/gmod/VMatrix) to the current net message.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: matrix
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The matrix to be sent.

WriteNormal.DESCRIPTION:
Writes a normalized/direction vector ( Vector with length of 1 ) to the net message.

This function uses less bandwidth compared to [net.WriteVector](/gmod/net.WriteVector) and will not send vectors with length of > 1 properly.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: normal
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The normalized/direction vector to be send.

WriteString.DESCRIPTION: Appends a string to the current net message. The size of the string is 8 bits plus 8 bits for every ASCII character in the string. The maximum allowed length of a single written string is 65533 characters.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: string
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The string to be sent.

WriteTable.DESCRIPTION: Appends a table to the current net message. Adds 16 extra bits per key/value pair so you're better off writing each individual key/value as the exact type if possible.
WARNINGS: All net messages have a 64kb buffer. This function will not check or error when that buffer is overflown. You might want to consider using util.TableToJSON and util.Compress and send the resulting string in 60kb chunks, doing the opposite on the receiving end.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: table
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The table to be sent.
WARNINGS:
If the table contains a nil key the table may not be read correctly.

Not all objects can be sent over the network. Things like functions, IMaterials, etc will cause errors when reading the table from a net message.

WriteType.DESCRIPTION: Appends any type of value to the current net message.
NOTES: An additional 8-bit unsigned integer indicating the type will automatically be written to the packet before the value, in order to facilitate reading with net.ReadType. If you know the data type you are writing, use a function meant for that specific data type to reduce amount of data sent.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: Data
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The data to be sent

WriteUInt.DESCRIPTION:
Appends an unsigned integer with the specified number of bits to the current net message.

Use [net.WriteInt](/gmod/net.WriteInt) if you want to send negative and positive numbers. Use [net.WriteFloat](/gmod/net.WriteFloat) for a non-whole number (e.g. 2.25).
NOTES: Unsigned numbers do not support negative numbers.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: unsignedInteger
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The unsigned integer to be sent.

WriteVector.DESCRIPTION:
Appends a vector to the current net message.
Vectors sent by this function are compressed, which may result in precision loss.  XYZ components greater than 16384 or less than -16384 are irrecoverably altered (most significant bits are trimmed) and precision after the decimal point is low.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: vector
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The vector to be sent.

net.DESCRIPTION:
The net library is one of a number of ways to send data between the client and server. 

The major advantages of the net library are the large size limit (64kb/message) and the ability to send data backwards - from the client to the server.

Refer to [Net Library Usage](/gmod/Net Library Usage) for a short introduction.

AddLegacy.DESCRIPTION: Adds a standard notification to your screen.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: text
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The text to display.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: type
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Determines the notification method (e.g. icon) for displaying the notification. See the [NOTIFY](/gmod/Enums/NOTIFY).

ARGUMENTS.NAME: length
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The number of seconds to display the notification for.

AddProgress.DESCRIPTION: Adds a notification with an animated progress bar.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: id
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Can be any type. It's used as an index.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: strText
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The text to show

ARGUMENTS.NAME: frac
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: If set, overrides the progress bar animation with given percentage. Range is 0 to 1.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: uid
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The unique ID of the notification

notification.DESCRIPTION: Used to display notifications on the screen (mid-right).

Activate.DESCRIPTION: Activates numpad key owned by the player

ARGUMENTS.NAME: ply
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The player whose numpad should be simulated

ARGUMENTS.NAME: key
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The key to press, see [KEY](/gmod/Enums/KEY)

ARGUMENTS.NAME: isButton
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Should this keypress pretend to be a from a gmod_button? (causes [numpad.FromButton](/gmod/numpad.FromButton) to return true)

Deactivate.DESCRIPTION: Deactivates numpad key owned by the player

ARGUMENTS.NAME: ply
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The player whose numpad should be simulated

ARGUMENTS.NAME: key
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The key to press, corresponding to [KEY](/gmod/Enums/KEY)

ARGUMENTS.NAME: isButton
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Should this keypress pretend to be a from a gmod_button? (causes [numpad.FromButton](/gmod/numpad.FromButton) to return true)

FromButton.DESCRIPTION:
Returns true during a function added with [numpad.Register](/gmod/numpad.Register) when the third argument to [numpad.Activate](/gmod/numpad.Activate) is true.

This is caused when a numpad function is triggered by a button SENT being used.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: wasButton

OnDown.DESCRIPTION:
Calls a function registered with [numpad.Register](/gmod/numpad.Register) when a player presses specified key.

See for key released action: [numpad.OnUp](/gmod/numpad.OnUp)

ARGUMENTS.NAME: ply
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The player whose numpad should be watched

ARGUMENTS.NAME: key
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The key, corresponding to [KEY](/gmod/Enums/KEY)

ARGUMENTS.NAME: name
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The name of the function to run, corresponding with the one used in [numpad.Register](/gmod/numpad.Register)
Arguments to pass to the function passed to [numpad.Register](/gmod/numpad.Register).

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The impulse ID

OnUp.DESCRIPTION:
Calls a function registered with [numpad.Register](/gmod/numpad.Register) when a player releases specified key.

See for key pressed action: [numpad.OnDown](/gmod/numpad.OnDown)

ARGUMENTS.NAME: ply
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The player whose numpad should be watched

ARGUMENTS.NAME: key
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The key, corresponding to [KEY](/gmod/Enums/KEY)

ARGUMENTS.NAME: name
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The name of the function to run, corresponding with the one used in [numpad.Register](/gmod/numpad.Register)
Arguments to pass to the function passed to [numpad.Register](/gmod/numpad.Register).

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The impulse ID

Register.DESCRIPTION: Registers a numpad library action for use with [numpad.OnDown](/gmod/numpad.OnDown) and [numpad.OnUp](/gmod/numpad.OnUp)

ARGUMENTS.NAME: id
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The unique id of your action.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: func
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION:
The function to be executed.

Arguments are:

[Player](/gmod/Player) ply - The player who pressed the button

[vararg](/gmod/vararg) ... - The 4th and all subsequent arguments passed from [numpad.OnDown](/gmod/numpad.OnDown) and/or [numpad.OnUp](/gmod/numpad.OnUp)

Returning **false** in this function will remove the listener which triggered this function (example: return false if one of your varargs is an entity which is no longer valid)

Remove.DESCRIPTION: Removes a function added by either [numpad.OnUp](/gmod/numpad.OnUp) or [numpad.OnDown](/gmod/numpad.OnDown)

ARGUMENTS.NAME: ID
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The impulse ID returned by [numpad.OnUp](/gmod/numpad.OnUp) or [numpad.OnDown](/gmod/numpad.OnDown)

Toggle.DESCRIPTION: Either runs [numpad.Activate](/gmod/numpad.Activate) or [numpad.Deactivate](/gmod/numpad.Deactivate) depending on the key's current state

ARGUMENTS.NAME: ply
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The player whose numpad should be simulated

ARGUMENTS.NAME: key
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The key to press, corresponding to [KEY](/gmod/Enums/KEY)

numpad.DESCRIPTION: The numpad module allows you to execute functions on a key press or release.

clock.DESCRIPTION:
Returns the approximate cpu time the application ran.

See also [SysTime](/gmod/Global.SysTime)
NOTES: This function has different precision on Linux (1/100).

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: runtime

date.DESCRIPTION: Returns the date/time as a formatted string or in a table.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: format
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION:
The format string.

If this is equal to `*t` or `!*t` then this function will return a [DateData](/gmod/Structures/DateData), otherwise it will return a string.

If this starts with an `!`, the returned data will use the UTC timezone rather than the local timezone.

See http://www.mkssoftware.com/docs/man3/strftime.3.asp for available format flags.

Known formats that work on all platforms:

| Format | Description | Example of the output |

|:------:|:-----------:|:---------------------:|

| `%a` | Abbreviated weekday name | `Wed` |

| `%A` | Full weekday name | `Wednesday` |

| `%b` | Abbreviated month name | `Sep` |

| `%B` | Full month name | `September` |

| `%c` | Date and time (Same as `%a %b %d %H:%M:%S %Y`) | `Wed Sep 16 09/16/98 23:48:10` |

| `%d` | Day of the month [01-31] | `16` |

| `%H` | Hour, using a 24-hour clock [00-23] | `23` |

| `%I` | Hour, using a 12-hour clock [01-12] | `11` |

| `%j` | Day of the year [001-365] | `259` |

| `%m` | Month [01-12] | `09` |

| `%M` | Minute [00-59] | `48` |

| `%p` | Either `am` or `pm` | `pm` |

| `%S` | Second [00-60] | `10` |

| `%w` | Weekday [0-6 = Sunday-Saturday] | `3` |

| `%W` | Week of the year [00-53] | `37` |

| `%x` | Date (Same as `%m/%d/%y`) | `09/16/98` |

| `%X` | Time (Same as `%H:%M:%S`) | `24:48:10` |

| `%y` | Two-digit year [00-99] | `98` |

| `%Y` | Full year | `1998` |

| `%z` | Timezone | `-0300` |

| `%%` | A percent sign | `%` |

BUGS.DESCRIPTION: **Not all flags are available on all operating systems** and the result of using an invalid flag is undefined. This currently crashes the game on Windows. Most or all flags are available on OS X and Linux but considerably fewer are available on Windows. See http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/fe06s4ak.aspx for a list of available flags on Windows. Note that the **#** flags also crashes the game on Windows.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: time
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Time to use for the format.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: Formatted date
NOTES: This will be a Structures/DateData if the first argument equals to `*t` or `!*t`

difftime.DESCRIPTION: Subtracts the second from the first value and rounds the result.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: timeA
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The first value.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: timeB
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The value to subtract.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: diffTime

time.DESCRIPTION: Returns the system time in seconds past the unix epoch. If a table is supplied, the function attempts to build a system time with the specified table members.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: dateData
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Table to generate the time from. This table's data is interpreted as being in the local timezone. See [DateData](/gmod/Structures/DateData)

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: Seconds passed since Unix epoch

os.DESCRIPTION: The os library is a standard Lua library originally intended to allow Lua access to various features of the Operating System it's running on, however many of the features and functions have been removed in Garry's Mod due to security issues. It's only used in Garry's Mod for date & time operations.

seeall.DESCRIPTION: Sets a metatable for module with its __index field referring to the global environment, so that this module inherits values from the global environment. To be used as an option to [module](/gmod/Global.module).

ARGUMENTS.NAME: module
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The module table to be given a metatable

package.DESCRIPTION: The package library is a standard Lua library, it's mainly for use with the module system built into Lua.

AddSurfaceData.DESCRIPTION: Adds surface properties to the game's physics environment.

BUGS.DESCRIPTION: The game has a limit of 128 surface properties - this includes properties loaded automatically from [surfaceproperties.txt](https://github.com/Facepunch/garrysmod/blob/master/garrysmod/scripts/surfaceproperties.txt). Due to this, there's only a small amount of open slots that can be registered with GMod's provided surfaceproperties.txt.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: properties
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The properties to add. Each one should include "base" or the game will crash due to some values being missing.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: airDensity
gravity

GetPerformanceSettings.DESCRIPTION: Gets the current performance settings in table form.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: Performance settings. See [PhysEnvPerformanceSettings](/gmod/Structures/PhysEnvPerformanceSettings)

ARGUMENTS.NAME: airDensity
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The new air density.

SetGravity.DESCRIPTION: Sets the directional gravity, does not work on players.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: gravity
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The new gravity.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: performanceSettings
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The new performance settings. See [PhysEnvPerformanceSettings](/gmod/Structures/PhysEnvPerformanceSettings)

physenv.DESCRIPTION: The physenv library allows you to control the physics environment created by the engine, and lets you modify constants such as gravity and maximum velocity.

CreateNextBot.DESCRIPTION:
Similar to the serverside command "bot", this function creates a new Player bot with the given name. This bot will not obey to the usual "bot_*" commands, and it's the same bot base used in TF2 and CS:S.

The best way to control the behaviour of a Player bot right now is to use the [GM:StartCommand](/gmod/GM:StartCommand) hook and modify its input serverside.
NOTES: Any Bot created using this method will be considered UnAuthed by Garry's Mod

Despite this Player being fake, it has to be removed from the server by using Player:Kick and **NOT** Entity:Remove.

Also keep in mind that these bots still use player slots, so you won't be able to spawn them in singleplayer!

ARGUMENTS.NAME: botName
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION:
The name of the bot, using an already existing name will append brackets at the end of it with a number pertaining it.

Example: "Bot name test", "Bot name test(1)".

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The newly created Player bot. Returns NULL if there's no Player slots available to host it.

GetAll.DESCRIPTION: Gets all the current players in the server (not including connecting clients).
NOTES: This function returns bots as well as human players. See player.GetBots and  player.GetHumans.
This function returns a sequential table, meaning it should be looped with Global.ipairs instead of Global.pairs for efficiency reasons.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: All [Player](/gmod/Player)s currently in the server.

GetBots.DESCRIPTION: Returns a table of all bots on the server.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: A table only containing bots ( AI / non human players )

GetByAccountID.DESCRIPTION: Gets the player with the specified AccountID.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: accountID
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The [Player:AccountID](/gmod/Player:AccountID) to find the player by.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: Player if one is found, false otherwise.

GetByID.DESCRIPTION:
Gets the player with the specified connection ID.

Connection ID can be retrieved via [gameevent.Listen](/gmod/gameevent.Listen) events.

For a function that returns a player based on their [Entity:EntIndex](/gmod/Entity:EntIndex), see [Entity](/gmod/Global.Entity).

For a function that returns a player based on their [Player:UserID](/gmod/Player:UserID), see [Player](/gmod/Global.Player).

ARGUMENTS.NAME: connectionID
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The connection ID to find the player by.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: Player if one is found, nil otherwise

GetBySteamID.DESCRIPTION: Gets the player with the specified SteamID.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: steamID
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The [Player:SteamID](/gmod/Player:SteamID) to find the player by.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: Player if one is found, false otherwise.

GetBySteamID64.DESCRIPTION: Gets the player with the specified SteamID64.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: steamID64
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The [Player:SteamID64](/gmod/Player:SteamID64) to find the player by. Also accepts numbers.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: Player if one is found, false otherwise.

GetByUniqueID.DESCRIPTION: Gets the player with the specified uniqueID (not recommended way to identify players).
WARNINGS: It is highly recommended to use player.GetByAccountID, player.GetBySteamID or player.GetBySteamID64 instead as this function can have collisions ( be same for different people ) while SteamID is guaranteed to unique to each player.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: uniqueID
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The [Player:UniqueID](/gmod/Player:UniqueID) to find the player by.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: Player if one is found, false otherwise.

NOTES: Similar to **#**player.GetAll() but with better performance since the player table doesn't have to be generated. If player.GetAll is already being called for iteration, then using the **#** operator on the table will be faster than calling this function since it is JITted.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: Number of players

GetHumans.DESCRIPTION:
Returns a table of all human ( non bot/AI ) players.

Unlike [player.GetAll](/gmod/player.GetAll), this does not include bots.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: A table of all human ( non bot/AI ) players.

player.DESCRIPTION: The player library is used to get the Lua objects that represent players in-game.

AddValidHands.DESCRIPTION: Assigns view model hands to player model.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: name
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Player model name

ARGUMENTS.NAME: model
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Hands model

ARGUMENTS.NAME: skin
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Skin to apply to the hands

ARGUMENTS.NAME: bodygroups
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Bodygroups to apply to the hands

AddValidModel.DESCRIPTION:
Associates a simplified name with a path to a valid player model.

Only used internally.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: name
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Simplified name

ARGUMENTS.NAME: model
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Valid PlayerModel path

AllValidModels.DESCRIPTION: Returns the entire list of valid player models.

ClearPlayerClass.DESCRIPTION: Clears a player's class association by setting their ClassID to 0

ARGUMENTS.NAME: ply
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Player to clear class from

ARGUMENTS.NAME: ply
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Player to get class

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The players class

GetPlayerClasses.DESCRIPTION: Retrieves a copy of all registered player classes.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: A copy of all registered player classes.

OnPlayerSpawn.DESCRIPTION:
Applies basic class variables when the player spawns.

Called from [GM:PlayerSpawn](/gmod/GM:PlayerSpawn) in the base gamemode.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: ply
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Player to setup

RegisterClass.DESCRIPTION: Register a class metatable to be assigned to players later

ARGUMENTS.NAME: name
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Class name

ARGUMENTS.NAME: table
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Class metatable

ARGUMENTS.NAME: base
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Base class name

RunClass.DESCRIPTION: Execute a named function within the player's set class

ARGUMENTS.NAME: ply
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Player to execute function on.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: funcName
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Name of function.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: arguments
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Optional arguments. Can be of any type.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The values returned by the called function.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: ply
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Player to set class

ARGUMENTS.NAME: classname
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Name of class to set

TranslatePlayerHands.DESCRIPTION: Retrieves correct hands for given player model. By default returns citizen hands.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: name
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Player model name

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION:
A table with following contents:
* [string](/gmod/string) model - Model of hands
* [number](/gmod/number) skin - Skin of hands
* [string](/gmod/string) body - Bodygroups of hands

TranslatePlayerModel.DESCRIPTION: Returns the valid model path for a simplified name.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: shortName
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The short name of the model.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The valid model path for the short name.

TranslateToPlayerModelName.DESCRIPTION:
Returns the simplified name for a valid model path of a player model.

Opposite of [player_manager.TranslatePlayerModel](/gmod/player_manager.TranslatePlayerModel).

ARGUMENTS.NAME: model
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The model path to a player model

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The simplified name for that model

player_manager.DESCRIPTION: The player_manager library lets you manage players, such as setting their models or creating player classes.

Add.DESCRIPTION: Adds preset to a preset group.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: groupname
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The preset group name, usually it's tool class name.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: name
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Preset name, must be unique.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: values
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: A table of preset console commands.

BadNameAlert.DESCRIPTION: Used internally to tell the player that the name they tried to use in their preset is not acceptable.

Exists.DESCRIPTION: Returns whether a preset with given name exists or not

ARGUMENTS.NAME: type
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The preset group name, usually it's tool class name.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: name
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Name of the preset to test

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: true if the preset does exist

GetTable.DESCRIPTION: Returns a table with preset names and values from a single preset group.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: groupname
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Preset group name.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: All presets in specified group.

OverwritePresetPrompt.DESCRIPTION: Used internally to ask the player if they want to override an already existing preset.

Remove.DESCRIPTION: Removes a preset entry from a preset group.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: groupname
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Preset group to remove from

ARGUMENTS.NAME: name
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Name of preset to remove

ARGUMENTS.NAME: groupname
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Preset group name

ARGUMENTS.NAME: oldname
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Old preset name

ARGUMENTS.NAME: newname
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: New preset name

presets.DESCRIPTION: The presets library lets you add and modify the pre-set options for scripted tools (selected via the white bar at the top of each tools control panel).

Add.DESCRIPTION: Add properties to the properties module

ARGUMENTS.NAME: name
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: A unique name used to identify the property

ARGUMENTS.NAME: propertyData
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: A table that defines the property. Uses the [PropertyAdd](/gmod/Structures/PropertyAdd).

CanBeTargeted.DESCRIPTION:
Returns true if given entity can be targeted by the player via the properties system.

This should be used serverside in your properties to prevent abuse by clientside scripting.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: ent
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The entity to test

ARGUMENTS.NAME: ply
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: If given, will also perform a distance check based on the entity's Orientated Bounding Box.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: True if entity can be targeted, false otherwise

GetHovered.DESCRIPTION: Returns an entity player is hovering over with his cursor.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: pos
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Eye position of local player, [Entity:EyePos](/gmod/Entity:EyePos)

ARGUMENTS.NAME: aimVec
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Aim vector of local player, [Player:GetAimVector](/gmod/Player:GetAimVector)

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: The hovered entity

OnScreenClick.DESCRIPTION: Checks if player hovers over any entities and open a properties menu for it.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: eyepos
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The eye pos of a player

ARGUMENTS.NAME: eyevec
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The aim vector of a player

OpenEntityMenu.DESCRIPTION: Opens properties menu for given entity.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: ent
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The entity to open menu for

ARGUMENTS.NAME: tr
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The trace that is passed as second argument to Action callback of a property

properties.DESCRIPTION: The properties library gives you access to the menu that shows up when right clicking entities while holding C.

AddBeam.DESCRIPTION: Adds a beam segment to the beam started by [render.StartBeam](/gmod/render.StartBeam).

ARGUMENTS.NAME: startPos
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Beam start position.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: width
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The width of the beam.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: textureEnd
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The end coordinate of the texture used.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: color
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The color to be used. Uses the [Color](/gmod/Color).

BlurRenderTarget.DESCRIPTION: Blurs the render target ( or a given texture )

ARGUMENTS.NAME: rendertarget
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The texture to blur

ARGUMENTS.NAME: blurx
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Horizontal amount of blur

ARGUMENTS.NAME: blury
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Vertical amount of blur

ARGUMENTS.NAME: passes
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Amount of passes to go through

BrushMaterialOverride.DESCRIPTION: This function overrides the brush material for next render operations. It can be used with [Entity:DrawModel](/gmod/Entity:DrawModel).

Capture.DESCRIPTION:
Captures a part of the current render target and returns the data as a binary string in the given format.

Since the pixel buffer clears itself every frame, this will return a black screen outside of. To capture the user's final view, use [GM:PostRender](/gmod/GM:PostRender). This will not capture the Steam overlay or third-party injections (such as the Discord overlay, Overwolf, and advanced cheats) on the user's screen.

BUGS.DESCRIPTION: This sets the alpha channel incorrectly in PNG mode, causing the foreground to be rendered almost completely transparent.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: captureData
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Parameters of the capture. See [RenderCaptureData](/gmod/Structures/RenderCaptureData).

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: binaryData

CapturePixels.DESCRIPTION: Dumps the current render target and allows the pixels to be accessed by [render.ReadPixel](/gmod/render.ReadPixel).

Clear.DESCRIPTION: Clears the current render target and the specified buffers.

BUGS.DESCRIPTION: This sets the alpha incorrectly for [surface](/gmod/surface) draw calls for render targets.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: r
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Red component to clear to.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: g
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Green component to clear to.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: b
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Blue component to clear to.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: a
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Alpha component to clear to.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: clearDepth
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Clear the depth.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: clearStencil
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Clear the stencil.

ClearBuffersObeyStencil.DESCRIPTION: Clears the current rendertarget for obeying the current stencil buffer conditions.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: r
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Value of the **red** channel to clear the current rt with.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: g
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Value of the **green** channel to clear the current rt with.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: b
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Value of the **blue** channel to clear the current rt with.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: a
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Value of the **alpha** channel to clear the current rt with.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: depth
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Clear the depth buffer.

BUGS.DESCRIPTION: This function also clears the stencil buffer. Use [render.Clear](/gmod/render.Clear) in the meantime.

ClearRenderTarget.DESCRIPTION:
Clears a render target

It uses [render.Clear](/gmod/render.Clear) then [render.SetRenderTarget](/gmod/render.SetRenderTarget) on the modified render target.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: color
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The color, see [Color](/gmod/Color)

ClearStencil.DESCRIPTION: Resets all values in the stencil buffer to zero.

ClearStencilBufferRectangle.DESCRIPTION:
Sets the stencil value in a specified rect.

This is **not** affected by [render.SetStencilWriteMask](/gmod/render.SetStencilWriteMask)

ARGUMENTS.NAME: originX
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: X origin of the rectangle.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: originY
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Y origin of the rectangle.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: endX
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The end X coordinate of the rectangle.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: endY
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The end Y coordinate of the rectangle.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: stencilValue
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Value to set cleared stencil buffer to.

ComputeDynamicLighting.DESCRIPTION: Calculates the lighting caused by dynamic lights for the specified surface.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: position
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The position to sample from.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: normal
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The normal of the surface.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: A vector representing the light at that point.

ComputeLighting.DESCRIPTION: Calculates the light color of a certain surface.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: position
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The position of the surface to get the light from.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: normal
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The normal of the surface to get the light from.

RETURNS.DESCRIPTION: A vector representing the light at that point.

CopyRenderTargetToTexture.DESCRIPTION: Copies the currently active Render Target to the specified texture.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: Target
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The texture to copy to

CopyTexture.DESCRIPTION: Copies the contents of one texture to another. Only works with rendertargets.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: cullMode
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Cullmode, see [MATERIAL_CULLMODE](/gmod/Enums/MATERIAL_CULLMODE)

DepthRange.DESCRIPTION: Set's the depth range of the upcoming render.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: depthmin
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The minimum depth of the upcoming render. `0.0` = render normally; `1.0` = render nothing.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: depthmax
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The maximum depth of the upcoming render. `0.0` = render everything (through walls); `1.0` = render normally.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: startPos
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Beam start position.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: endPos
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Beam end position.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: width
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The width of the beam.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: textureStart
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The start coordinate of the texture used.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: textureEnd
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The end coordinate of the texture used.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: color
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The color to be used. Uses the [Color](/gmod/Color).

ARGUMENTS.NAME: position
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Origin of the box.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: angles
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Orientation of the box.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: mins
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Start position of the box, relative to origin.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: maxs
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: End position of the box, relative to origin.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: color
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The color of the box. Uses the [Color](/gmod/Color).

ARGUMENTS.NAME: startPos
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Line start position in world coordinates.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: endPos
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Line end position in world coordinates.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: color
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The color to be used. Uses the [Color](/gmod/Color).

ARGUMENTS.NAME: writeZ
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Whether or not to consider the Z buffer. If false, the line will be drawn over everything currently drawn, if true, the line will be drawn with depth considered, as if it were a regular object in 3D space.

BUGS.DESCRIPTION: Enabling this option will cause the line to ignore the color's alpha.

DrawQuad.DESCRIPTION: Draws 2 connected triangles. Expects material to be set by [render.SetMaterial](/gmod/render.SetMaterial).

ARGUMENTS.NAME: vert1
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: First vertex.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: vert2
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The second vertex.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: vert3
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The third vertex.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: vert4
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The fourth vertex.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: color
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The color of the quad. See [Color](/gmod/Global.Color)

ARGUMENTS.NAME: position
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: Origin of the sprite.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: normal
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The face direction of the quad.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: width
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The width of the quad.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: height
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The height of the quad.

ARGUMENTS.NAME: color
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The color of the quad. Uses the [Color](/gmod/Color).

ARGUMENTS.NAME: rotation
ARGUMENTS.DESCRIPTION: The rotation of the quad counter-clockwise in degrees around the normal axis. In other words, the quad will always face the same way but this will rotate its corners.

DrawScreenQuad.DESCRIPTION:
Draws the current material set by [render.SetMaterial](/gmod/render.SetMaterial) to the whole screen. The color cannot be customized.

See also [render.DrawScreenQuadEx](/gmod/render.DrawScreenQuadEx).

ARGUMENTS.NAME: applyPoster
